docs.lead_paragraph: PROJECT Hospitality's food bank on the north shore of Staten Island provides more than 460,000 meals a year to New Yorkers, many of whom are homeless or disabled. A federally financed program helps local churches organize food drives to supply the food bank with donations. But the money that pays for such innovative efforts to combat hunger will be eliminated if the budget package passed by the House of Representatives just before Thanksgiving becomes law in a few weeks. The loss of this community-based anti-hunger program on Staten Island is probably the smallest of the many changes facing Americans if the House gets its way, but it's an apt metaphor for the cuts, which threaten to undermine both the independence and sustenance of thousands of poor New Yorkers. The final budget package is likely to come to a vote in Congress just in time for the holidays. It may well be remembered as the gift that keeps on taking for years to come.

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a small plot of land in North White Plains, low-income women have been planting and harvesting their own squash, collard greens and tomatoes for the last three years. For the women, many of whom are returning to work after struggles with domestic violence and mental illness, the garden provides a lesson in self-sufficiency even as it lowers their food bills. Yet the money that pays for such innovative efforts to combat hunger will be eliminated if the budget package passed by the House of Representatives just before Thanksgiving becomes law in a few weeks. The loss of the little garden is probably the smallest of the many changes facing Americans if the House gets its way, but it's an apt metaphor for the cuts, which threaten to undermine both the independence and sustenance of thousands of poor New Yorkers. The final budget package is likely to come to a vote in Congress just in time for the holidays. It may well be remembered as the gift that keeps on taking for years to come.

docs.lead_paragraph: The story is similar to what it was three years ago: five days from a contract deadline for New York City transit workers, the two sides, represented by the same powerful and colorful leaders, have dug in for intense, possibly round-the-clock negotiations. But if the showdown is similar, the source of contention has shifted significantly. This time, a dispute over pensions and health benefits -- rather than wages -- has emerged as the central obstacle to a deal.

headline.main: In Talks Over Transit Pact, Different Chips, Same Poker

docs.snippet: Pensions and health benefits are at the center of a dispute between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and transit workers.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and SEWELL CHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Wayne B. Eisman, president of ENT and Allergy Associates' board, blames long waits in doctors' offices on low insurance reimbursements that force physicians to increase their patient rosters. Excessive waiting times are actually a function of scheduling and were common for years before health maintenance organizations and Medicare even existed.

headline.main: Doctors and Patients Fighting a Giant

docs.lead_paragraph: As one of more than two million Americans who rushed to a courthouse this year to file for bankruptcy before a tough new law took effect, Laura Fogle is glad for her chance at a fresh start. A nurse and single mother of two, she blames her use of credit cards after cancer surgery for falling into deep debt. Ms. Fogle is broke, and may not seem to be the kind of person to whom banks would want to offer credit cards. But she said she had no sooner filed for bankruptcy, and sworn off plastic, than she was hit with a flurry of solicitations from major banks.

headline.main: Newly Bankrupt Raking In Piles Of Credit Offers

docs.snippet: Credit card companies are soliciting the more than two million Americans who rushed to file for bankruptcy this year before a tough new law took effect.

For the women, many of whom are returning to work after struggles with domestic violence and mental illness, the garden provides a lesson in self-sufficiency even as it lowers their food bills. docs.lead_paragraph: An unexpected takeover battle between Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson for control of Guidant seems bound to send aftershocks through the medical device industry. There is widespread speculation about the effects on prominent competitors like Medtronic and St. Jude Medical in Guidant's main business of electrical implants that regulate heart functioning. Investors and analysts also wonder who will end up with Guidant's business of making stents and other devices used to treat circulatory illnesses.
docs.abstract: Boston Scientific's bid to acquire Guidant, maker of stents and other devices used to treat circulatory illnesses, raises questions about its 15 percent stake in Cyberonics, whose implanted nerve-stimulation device, VNS Therapy System, was approved in July for treatment of severe depression; Medicare and many major insurers continue to classify treatment as experimental, and there are conflicting views on Wall Street of technology's prospects; there are reports that Boston Scientific might sell its stake in Cyberonics to raise cash if its bid for Guidant is successful; among potential buyers would be Johnson & Johnson, Boston Scientific's rival for Guidant; photo (M)
docs.snippet: An unexpected takeover battle between Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson for control of Guidant seems bound to send aftershocks through the medical device industry.      There is widespread speculation about the effects on prominent competitors...

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at two major hospitals in the New York region said this week that the financial troubles they had faced in recent years appeared to be abating. Westchester Medical Center is expecting a surplus, and the Nassau Health Care Corporation, which runs Nassau University Medical Center, expects to break even next year. Both hospitals faltered after becoming independent of their respective county governments in the late 1990's -- running large deficits, laying off hundreds of employees and bringing in new management teams to try to turn things around.

headline.main: 2 County Hospitals Expect to End Their Budget Deficits

docs.snippet: Officials at two major hospitals in the New York region said this week that the financial troubles they had faced in recent years appeared to be abating. Westchester Medical Center is expecting a surplus, and the Nassau Health Care Corporation, which...

byline.original: By LISA W. FODERARO and BRUCE LAMBERT

docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday offered subway and bus workers a two-year contract with raises of 3 percent next year and 2 percent the following year -- a more generous wage proposal than it made during the last contract talks, in 2002 -- but insisted that new employees pay 2 percent of their earnings toward health care premiums. Roger Toussaint, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, said the proposal as a whole was unacceptable. He said that the 3 percent offer was ''a starting point,'' but that the health insurance proposal, along with a demand that new employees be ineligible to collect full pensions until age 62, was ''aimed at creating a divided work force.''
docs.snippet: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the offer insisted that new employees pay 2 percent of their earnings toward health care premiums.

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN; Mike McIntire contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: When stumping through the port city of Alexandria, whose crumbling mansions and rickety tram lines evoke long-faded glory, Sobhe Saleh of the Muslim Brotherhood vowed he had a different vision for Egypt's future. ''If Islam were applied, no one would be hungry,'' he roared recently to a crowd of fully veiled women ululating with joy. ''Islam is a religion of construction. Islam is a religion of investment. Islam is a religion of development.''

headline.main: Will Politics and Success at the Polls Tame Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood?
headline.kicker: Stirrings in the Desert | Islamists as Players

docs.snippet: The Islamist group gained parliamentary seats, raising the question whether success will moderate its image.

multimedia.credit: A day of reckoning is at hand in Egyptian politics now that the Muslim Brotherhood is entering the corridors of power.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: A day of reckoning is at hand in Egyptian politics now that the Muslim Brotherhood is entering the corridors of power.

multimedia.caption: Muslim Brotherhood Gains Ground
